children.name: be used
children.definition: /biː ˈjuːzd/  được sử dụng

children.name: be used as được sử dụng như
examples: ▪ Three extra rooms were used as classrooms when necessary.
▪ An old Chianti bottle can be used as an attractive base for a table-lamp.

children.name: be used for được sử dụng cho
examples: ▪ The tanks are used for storing chemicals.

children.name: be used to do something được sử dụng để làm gì
examples: ▪ Hypnosis is sometimes used to help people give up smoking.

children.name: be for
children.definition: /biː ˈfɔːʳ/  to be intended to be used for a particular purpose: để sử dụng

children.name: ▪ ‘What are these buttons for?’ ‘They’re for controlling the heating system.’
examples: ▪ The phones are for internal communication only.

children.name: serve as
children.definition: /ˈsɜːʳv æz/  to be used for a particular purpose, especially a different purpose from its original one: phục vụ như, dùng như
examples: ▪ The old hospital in London Road now serves as a hostel for the homeless.
▪ They had no bathroom, so a hole in the ground served as a toilet.

children.name: double as
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive phrasal verb not usually in progressive]
children.definition: /ˈdʌbəl æz/  if something doubles as something else, it is used for that purpose as well as for its original purpose: được sử đụng đồng thời
examples: ▪ The village post-office doubles as a store.
▪ Lingerie that doubles as clothing was very fashionable at the time.

children.name: what you want to achieve when doing sth
purpose
children.definition: the purpose of sth is what it is intended to achieve : mục đích
examples: purpose of
The purpose of this meeting is to elect a new chairman.
What is the purpose of your visit?
sb’s purpose in doing sth
My purpose in writing this book was to draw attention to the problem of global warming
for this/that purpose
Read up on starting a small business. Loans can be obtained for this purpose.
the purpose of doing sth
The purpose of conducting a business is to make money.
for the purpose of doing sth
Troops were sent solely for the purpose of assisting refugees.
for medical/political/decorative etc purposes
It should be legitimate to use cannabis for medical purposes.
phrases

children.name: the main/primary purpose
examples: The main purpose of our trip to Arran was to see golden eagles.

children.name: the sole purpose
examples: I used to bake cakes for the sole purpose of giving them away.

children.name: the real purpose
examples: What was the real purpose of their visit?

children.name: the whole purpose
children.definition: used for emphasis
examples: The whole purpose of running a business is to make money.

children.name: sth’s original purpose
examples: The building is no longer needed for its original purpose.

children.name: a useful purpose
examples: Nuclear weapons serve no useful purpose and should be banned.

children.name: a practical purpose
examples: These materials are too fine to have a practical purpose in daily life.

children.name: a dual purpose
children.definition: two purposes
examples: A dog can fulfil a dual purpose by providing both company and security.

children.name: a common purpose
children.definition: one that people share
examples: We were bound together by a common purpose.

children.name: a specific/particular purpose
examples: Training is the acquisition of knowledge and skills for a specific purpose.

children.name: for political/military/educational/medicinal etc purposes
examples: This technology could be used for military purposes.

children.name: for business/research etc purposes
examples: About one in five of all trips are made for business purposes.

children.name: have a purpose
examples: A meeting should have a clear purpose.

children.name: serve/fulfil a purpose
children.definition: be used in a particular way
examples: The building must have served a religious purpose.|Many old school buildings are no longer suitable for fulfilling their original purpose.

children.name: achieve your purpose
children.definition: achieve what you wanted to achieve
examples: She had achieved her purpose, at least in part.

children.name: aim
children.definition: what you want to achieve when you do something
examples: aim of
The aim of the research is to find new food sources.
the aim is to do sth
The aim was to enroll all children in schools close to their homes.
with the aim of doing sth
a campaign with the aim of helping victims of crime
Teamwork is required in order toachievetheseaims.
a policy which sets out the school’saims and objectives
an educational aimthe educational aims of the school

children.name: the main/primary/principal aim
examples: The country’s main aim was to slow inflation.

children.name: the ultimate/eventual/long-term aim
children.definition: that you hope to achieve in the end
examples: The ultimate aim is to replace gasoline with non-polluting energy sources.

children.name: the immediate/initial/short-term aim
children.definition: that you hope to achieve quickly
examples: The immediate aim is to develop the travel business.

children.name: the overall/general/broad aim
children.definition: that concerns the main aim rather than all the details
examples: The overall aim of the project is to encourage young people to stay in higher education.|Guided by the general aim of the project, we aimed to reach a number of key objectives.

children.name: a specific aim
children.definition: an exact aim
examples: What are the specific aims of the course?

children.name: the underlying aim
children.definition: a basic aim, that people sometimes do not notice
examples: The games all have an underlying aim: survival.

children.name: a political aim
examples: We utterly condemn any acts of violence in pursuit of political aims.

children.name: a strategic aim
children.definition: that is part of a military, political, or business plan
examples: The broader strategic aims were to safeguard the Dutch East Indies against attack.

children.name: sb’s declared/stated aim
children.definition: an aim that somebody has stated clearly
examples: The Department’s declared aim is targeting benefits where they are most needed.

children.name: a common aim
children.definition: an aim that people, countries etc share
examples: We know the value of working closely together to pursue our common aims.

children.name: have an aim
examples: His trip to Milan, his third in two weeks, had a precise aim.

children.name: achieve/fulfil your aim
examples: The Internet bank achieved its aim of attracting 50,000 customers last year.|Once she had decided to go into publishing, she set out to fulfil her aim.

children.name: pursue your aims
children.definition: try to achieve them over a long period of time
examples: We worked closely together to pursue our common aims.

children.name: further your aims
children.definition: help them to progress or be successful
examples: The group is prepared to use violence to further its political aims.

children.name: set out the aims of something
examples: Is there a set of guidelines setting out the aims of study?

children.name: a set of aims
examples: The organization has a set of aims which are listed on its website.

children.name: aims and objectives
children.definition: the things you hope to achieve
examples: These aims and objectives are set out in chapters two and three.

children.name: point
children.definition: the purpose of something that you are doing or planning - use this especially when sb does not understand what the purpose is: mục đích
examples: point of
What’s the point of this meeting anyway?
the whole pointexactly the purpose of doing sth
The whole point of this TV show is to get you to buy Simmons’ exercise videos.
The whole point of this legislation is to protect children.
see the point of sthunderstand why someone does something: nhìn thấy mục tiêu
I can’t see the point of travelling all that way and then only staying for one day.
I didn’t see the point in moving to London.
miss the/somebody’s pointnot understand why someone does something: bỏ lỡ mục tiêu
You’re missing my point completely - I’m not talking about restructuring the department
what’s the point?use this when you think there is no good reason for something
Too many of these kids think, ‘What’s the point of going to college?’
I suppose we could save one or two of the trees, but what’s the point ?
There’s no point in
There’s no point in worrying.

children.name: idea
children.definition: the effect or result that you hope to achieve by doing something - use this especially when you are doubtful whether that effect or result can be achieved: ý định, ý tưởng
examples: We make toys that are both fun and educational - at least that’s the idea.

children.name: idea of
examples: The idea of the game is to get rid of all your cards as soon as you can.

children.name: whole idea(= only purpose)
examples: The whole idea of advertising is to make people buy things.

children.name: the idea is to do sth
examples: The idea of the centre was to provide a place where old people could go during the day.

children.name: the idea behind sth
examples: The idea behind the commercials is that reading is as cool and entertaining as their favorite bands.

children.name: objective
children.definition: formal the specific thing that you are trying to achieve – used especially about things that have been officially discussed and agreed upon in business, politics etc: mục tiêu
examples: The report focused on three of the business’s objectives.

children.name: have an objective
examples: Our main objective is to reduce road accidents.

children.name: set an objective
children.definition: decide what you are trying to achieve
examples: Pupils should be encouraged to set their own objectives.

children.name: achieve/accomplish an objective
children.definition: alsoattain an objectiveformal
examples: The policy should help us achieve our objective of reducing paper waste.

children.name: reach/meet an objective
children.definition: achieve an objective
examples: We need to control spending in order to meet our financial objectives.

children.name: pursue an objective
children.definition: try to achieve something you want
examples: War has always been a means of pursuing national objectives.

children.name: the main/principal objective
examples: This research project has three main objectives.

children.name: the primary/prime objective
children.definition: the main one
examples: The primary objective of training is to improve performance.

children.name: a key objective
children.definition: a very important objective
examples: Their economic strategy was based on a number of key objectives.

children.name: a clear objective
examples: A manager must give his team clear objectives to work towards.

children.name: a specific objective
examples: Most classroom activities have a specific learning objective.

children.name: a stated objective
children.definition: what someone says their objective is
examples: The city’s stated objective was to improve housing in the area.

children.name: a common objective
children.definition: one that people, countries etc share
examples: Our employees have a sense of common objectives and their commitment is high.

children.name: an economic/military/business/political etc objective
examples: We have made good progress towards meeting our business objectives.

children.name: aims and objectives
children.definition: all the things someone wants to achieve
examples: The department should clearly state its aims and objectives.

children.name: the objective is to do sth
examples: The objective of this computer game is to design a city.

children.name: object
children.definition: the specific intended result of a plan, action, or activity, especially when this may be difficult to achieve: mục tiêu, mục đích

children.name: the object of sth
examples: The object of the search was to find a small plane that has been missing for two days.

children.name: the object is to do sth
examples: In this game the object is to score as many points as you can in the time given.

children.name: the object of the exercise(= the main thing that you are trying to do)
examples: The object of the exercise is to keep kids in school, rather than let them leave without graduating.

children.name: The students will benefit, and that must be the object of the exercise
goal
children.definition: what a person, organization, or country hopes to achieve in the future, even though this might take quite a long time: mục tiêu (thời gian dài)
examples: Your goal as a parent is to help your child become an independent adult.

children.name: sb’s main/primary goal
examples: My main goal was to get the team to the finals.|The primary goal of the 1917 Revolution was to seize and redistribute the wealth of the Russian empire.

children.name: sb’s ultimate goal
children.definition: what they eventually and most importantly hope to achieve
examples: The ultimate goal is a freer, more democratic society.

children.name: an immediate goal
children.definition: that you need to achieve very soon
examples: Our immediate goal is to cut costs.

children.name: a long-term goal
children.definition: that you hope to achieve after a long time
examples: The organization’s long-term goal is to gain a strong position in the European market.

children.name: a short-term goal
children.definition: that you hope to achieve after a short time
examples: Companies should not focus only on the short-term goal of profitability.

children.name: sb’s personal goal
examples: They had to sacrifice personal goals for their family life.

children.name: a common goal
children.definition: an aim shared by more than one person or organization
examples: Iran and Turkey shared common goals in their handling of the refugee crisis.

children.name: an ambitious goal
children.definition: an aim that will be difficult to achieve
examples: The agreement set ambitious goals to cut greenhouse gas emissions worldwide.

children.name: a modest goal
children.definition: an aim that is not too difficult to achieve
examples: Don’t try to lose a lot of weight quickly; set yourself a more modest goal.

children.name: have a goal
examples: She had one goal in life: to accumulate a huge fortune.

children.name: work towards a goal
examples: We are all working towards similar goals.

children.name: pursue a goal
examples: Have we gone too far in pursuing the goal of national security?

children.name: achieve/attain/reach your goal
examples: She has worked hard to achieve her goal of a job in the medical profession.|They’re hoping to reach their goal of raising £10,000 for charity.

children.name: set
children.definition: yourself/somebody
examples: a goal(= decide what you or someone else should try to achieve )It helps if you set yourself clear goals.

children.name: goal of
examples: The goal of the partnership is to improve his company’s profit margin.

children.name: the goal is to do sth
examples: Her goal is to find a company willing to donate money for research.

children.name: Register
examples: In everyday British English, people often talk about what sbis aiming to dorather than talk about someone’sgoal:
His goal is toset up his own business.➔He’s aiming toset up his own business.

children.name: a realistic/achievable goalStudents are encouraged to set themselves realistic goals for academic improvement.|We pushed for what we thought were achievable goals
target
children.definition: the exact result that a person or organization intends to achieve by doing sth, often the amount of money they want to get: mục tiêu (con số)
examples: The target for the appeal is £20,000, all of which will go to children’s charities.
Our target is the release of all political prisoners.
target of
the target of a one-third reduction in road accidents
target for
Higher degrees in English are a target for foreign students.
on target(= likely to achieve a target)
The company says that growth of 10% is on target.
a target figureThe government has set a target figure of 6.2%

children.name: meet a target
children.definition: achieve what you want to achieve
examples: The government wants to meet its target of building three million new homes by 2020.

children.name: reach/achieve/hit a target
children.definition: meet it
examples: They achieved their target with just days to spare.

children.name: set a target
examples: The company has set ambitious business targets.

children.name: exceed a target
children.definition: achieve more than you wanted to
examples: We have exceeded our target of £200,000.

children.name: fall short of a target
children.definition: achieve less than you wanted to
examples: Car production at the plant has fallen short of its target by 5%.

children.name: ambitious/high
examples: The targets they have set themselves are hugely ambitious.

children.name: modest
children.definition: not very high
examples: The Kyoto Protocol set fairly modest targets for reductions in greenhouse gases.

children.name: achievable/realistic
examples: The target is achievable, but only by hard work.

children.name: a financial target
examples: Both businesses exceeded their financial targets.

children.name: a sales target
examples: I’m confident we will meet our sales target by the end of the year.

children.name: a growth target
examples: The company’s growth targets have been achieved for the last three years.

children.name: a target date
examples: There is no target date set for completion of the new project.

children.name: end
children.definition: the result that a person or group is trying to achieve, especially when this is bad or dishonest – used especially when you disapprove of what sb is doing: mục đích (xấu)
examples: They are using religion for political ends.

children.name: political/personal etc ends
examples: Racial tensions in Fiji were exaggerated for political ends by leaders of the opposition.

the end does not justify the meansthe way that someone tries to achieve something is wrong, even if what they want to achieve is good (= you should not use violence, cruelty, dishonest behaviour etc to achieve your aims).
The demonstrators’ ends do not justify their means.

children.name: what sth is intended to be used for
be for
children.definition: to be intended to be used for a particular purpose: dành cho
examples: This machine is for cleaning the carpet.
What’s this little button for?
These shoes are for running, and these are for sports such as basketball.

children.name: function
children.definition: the natural purpose of sth, such as a machine, tool, or piece of equipment, etc : chức năng
examples: Bauhaus architects thought that function was more important than form.
Each basket is designed to perform a specific function, from carrying corn to holding babies.

children.name: function of
examples: Several instructors could not answer questions about the function of a particular switch.
The function of this gene is to block the uncontrolled division of cells; it therefore prevents the development of cancer.
The function of the veins is to carry blood to the heart.
A thermostat performs the function of controlling temperature.
The nervous system regulates ourbodily functions(= eating, breathing, going to the toilet etc ).

children.name: perform/fulfil a function
examples: In your new job you will perform a variety of functions.
The church fulfils a valuable social function.

children.name: use
children.definition: a purpose that a machine, tool, plant etc can have: công dụng
examples: It’s main use is as a cleaning agent for metals.
Technology developed for the space program has civilian uses as well.
A food processor has a variety of uses in the kitchen.

children.name: use for
examples: Don't throw that cloth away, you'll find a use for it one day.
No, I don't want to buy a boat - I have no use for one!

children.name: to be intended for a particular purpose
to be meant to
children.definition: do sth to be done or made for a particular purpose, especially when the purpose is not achieved:
examples: His artworks are meant to cause debate.
The police opened the package and found not a bomb, but a wallet meant to be someone’s gift.

children.name: be intended to
children.definition: do sth to be done or made for a particular purpose: được dự định
examples: The concert is intended to raise money for charity.
I didn’t think the movie was as dramatic as it was intended to be.

children.name: dedicated
children.definition: specialized designed to be used for one particular purpose : chuyên dụng
examples: a dedicated computer
a dedicated sports channel

children.name: be designed to
children.definition: do sth to be made in a specific way in order to achieve a particular result:
examples: The menu was designed to appeal to both children and adults.
Democrats say the law is designed to help only wealthy taxpayers.

children.name: with the aim of
children.definition: doing sth if sth is done with the aim of achieving sth, it is done in order to try and achieve it: với mục đích là
examples: The center does research with the aim of improving the lives of poor Americans.
The committee will reform the tests, with the aim of better evaluating student performance.

children.name: with the express/deliberate etc aim of doing sth
examples: We ask students to write essays under examination conditions, with the deliberate aim of familiarizing them with these conditions.

children.name: to be supposed to
children.definition: do sth to be done or made for a particular purpose, especially when the purpose is not achieved:
examples: Thirty percent of the lottery ticket sales was supposed to go to education

children.name: sth that you want to achieve in your life
aspirations
children.definition: a word meaning the important things that people want from their lives, used especially when you are talking about all of society or large groups within it: nguyện vọng , ước nguyện
examples: A government should reflect the hopes, values and aspirations of society.
the aspirations of the people of Eastern Europe
aspirations for
What are our aspirations for the future?
The parents have very high aspirations for their children.
career/democratic/economic/political etc aspirations :
a handsome and rich young senator with presidential aspirations
high aspirationsnguyện vọng lớn
The immigrants who came to settle in America were determined people with high aspirations.

children.name: dream
children.definition: sth very special that you want to do and that you think about a lot, especially something that is not very likely to happen:
examples: Her dream is to make a movie.

children.name: have a dream/dreams
examples: I had dreams of becoming a doctor.

children.name: achieve/fulfil/realize a dream
children.definition: do or get what you want
examples: He had finally achieved his dream of winning an Olympic gold medal.

children.name: pursue/follow a dream
children.definition: try to do or get what you want
examples: She left her home town to pursue her dreams.

children.name: dream a dreamliterary
children.definition: have a wish
examples: We can dream great dreams for ourselves and others.

children.name: big/great dreams
children.definition: a wish to achieve great things
examples: She was a little girl with big dreams.

children.name: an impossible dream
children.definition: about something that cannot happen
examples: Having a number one record had seemed an impossible dream.

children.name: a childhood dream
children.definition: that you had when you were a child
examples: I had a childhood dream of becoming an astronaut.

children.name: a lifelong dream
children.definition: that you have had all your life
examples: His lifelong dream had been to write a novel.

children.name: a distant dream
children.definition: that it will take a long time to achieve
examples: Peace in this area may still be a distant dream.

children.name: a dream comes true
children.definition: something you want happens
examples: I’d always wanted to go to Africa and at last my dream came true.

children.name: the man/woman/house etc of your dreams
children.definition: the perfect one for you
examples: We can help you find the house of your dreams.

children.name: not/never in your wildest dreams
children.definition: used to say that you had never expected something to happen
examples: Never in my wildest dreams did I think I would win the competition.

children.name: beyond your wildest dreams
children.definition: better or more than you ever hoped for
examples: Suddenly he was wealthy beyond his wildest dreams.

children.name: sb’s dream is to do sth
examples: Her dream was to go to Hollywood and become a movie star.

children.name: dream of (doing) sth
examples: She had dreams of university.
I have just metthe man of my dreams(= the perfect man )!

children.name: ambition
children.definition: sth which you want to achieve in the future, especially in your career, and which you will try hard to achieve: tham vọng

children.name: sb’s ambition is to be/do sth
examples: My ambition was to be a journalist.

children.name: have an ambition
examples: He had an ambition to be a top cello player.

children.name: achieve/fulfil/realize your ambition
children.definition: do what you wanted to do
examples: It took her ten years to achieve her ambition.|He was prepared to go to any lengths to fulfil his ambition.|I want to thank all those who made it possible for me to realize a lifetime 's ambition.

children.name: lack ambition/have no ambition
examples: Many of the students lack ambition.

children.name: nurse/harbour/cherish an ambition
children.definition: have it for a long time, especially secretly
examples: He had nursed an ambition to become a writer for many years.

children.name: frustrate/thwart sb’s ambitionsformal
children.definition: prevent someone from achieving them
examples: The weather threatened to frustrate their ambitions.|Her lifelong ambitions had been thwarted again and again.

children.name: sb’s main ambition
examples: What’s your main ambition in life?

children.name: sb’s great ambition
examples: He didn’t achieve his greatest ambition – to be Wimbledon Champion.

children.name: a lifelong/long-held ambition
children.definition: one that you have had all your life
examples: It’s been her lifelong ambition to work with horses.

children.name: a personal ambition
examples: Crossing the Sahara was a personal ambition of mine.

children.name: a secret ambition
examples: His secret ambition was to become a pilot.

children.name: a burning/driving ambition
children.definition: a very strong ambition
examples: She had a burning ambition to become a racing car driver.

children.name: career ambitions
examples: The course is designed to help you achieve your career ambitions.

children.name: political/presidential ambitions
examples: His political ambitions were put on hold while he waited for a suitable opportunity.

children.name: sb’s dreams and ambitions
examples: He told her all about his dreams and ambitions.

children.name: sb’s lack of ambition
examples: I was frustrated by their apparent lack of ambition.

children.name: be full of ambition
examples: She was full of ambition when she joined the company.

children.name: an ambition to do sth
examples: She had always had an ambition to be a pilot.

children.name: sb’s ambition is to do sth
examples: Her ambition was to go to law school and become an attorney.

children.name: sb’s ambitions of doing sth
examples: An injury ended his ambitions of becoming a professional footballer.

children.name: to decide to use sth for a particular purpose
designate
children.definition: to officially choose sth for a particular purpose, often with the result that they cannot be used for anything else: chỉ định, khẳng định
examples: Designate a driver who won’t be drinking before going to a party or club.
designation[U] when a place or thing is designated
The area qualifies for designationasa site of special scientific interest.

children.name: designate sth as sth
examples: Mattos Elementary has been designated as this area’s ‘home’ school.

children.name: designate sth for sth
examples: One of the queues was designated for people with an EC passport.

children.name: designate sth to do sth
examples: $6 million has been designated to make road safety improvements on Pacheco Pass.

children.name: earmark
children.definition: to choose someone or something from among a larger group so that they can be used for a particular purpose in the future: đánh dấu, dành riêng

children.name: earmark sth for sth
examples: ▪ 20% of the budget has already been earmarked for a new computer system.

children.name: earmark sth to do sth
examples: ▪ The funds are earmarked to help pay for the cathedral’s renovation.

children.name: earmark sth as sth
examples: ▪ Dawson was earmarked as Reiner’s successor as District Attorney.

children.name: pointless
children.definition: something that is pointless has no purpose and makes you angry or sad: vô nghĩa

children.name: a film full of pointless violence
examples: Never give your students pointless exercises to do -- always provide interesting, meaningful tasks.

children.name: be pointless to do sth
examples: It is pointless to argue about who is more to blame.

children.name: aimless
children.definition: not having any purpose or plan and therefore boring or sad: không mục tiêu,
examples: The novel seems aimless, and the characters are stereotypes.
She changed from an aimless, pregnant teenager into a purposeful young woman.
a young man drifting through life in an aimless way
aimlessly[adv]
John wandered aimlessly all day and returned to his gloomy room in the evening.

children.name: senseless
children.definition: a crime or something bad that is senseless seems to have no meaning or purpose and you cannot understand why sb would do it: vô nghĩa, điên rồ, lãng xẹt
examples: It was a senseless and cruel murder.
Smashing up trains is such a senseless form of vandalism.
The suicide was described as a senseless waste of a young woman’s life.

children.name: meaningless
children.definition: having no purpose or importance and therefore not worth doing or having : vô nghĩa
examples: So many of us spend our lives doing meaningless work in huge faceless companies.
He said a few meaningless words to his hostess and looked around the room.
a repetitive and meaningless task
absolutely/utterly/completely meaningless
a statistic that is absolutely meaningless
virtually/fairly/largely meaningless

children.name: lack direction
children.definition: /lack of direction if sth lacks direction or has a lack of direction, it does not have a clear purpose and is not well organized: mất phương hướng,
examples: It could have been a good film, but I felt it lacked direction.
He quit over the company’s lack of direction.

children.name: purpose
children.definition: a plan or aim :
examples: Nickhad no particular purpose in mindwhen he started.

children.name: sb’s purpose in doing something
examples: Attending the race was not my purpose in coming to Indianapolis.

children.name: with the purpose of doing something
examples: He came here with the purpose of carrying out the attack.

children.name: will
children.definition: what someone wants to happen in a particular situation : ý chí, ý định, ý muốn
examples: He accused her of trying toimposeherwillon others.
It was God's will.
obedience to God’s will
will of
the will of the people
against your will
Collier claims the police forced him to sign a confession against his will.
Againsttheir will, they were forced to hold a meeting.
The government has failed to impose its willuponregional communities (= to make them do as it wants) .

children.name: way
children.definition: / ˈweɪ /nouninformal(WANT)
examples: C1 If someone gets or has their way, what they want happens:
If she doesn't get/have her (own) way, she sulks like a four-year-old.

children.name: towards
children.definition: mainlyUK/ towardmainly USfor the purpose of buying or achieving sth
examples: I'm saving up to buy a car, and Dad hasgiven me some money towards it.
Would you like to make a contribution (= give some money) towards a present for Linda?
The work that students do during the term counts towards their final grade.

children.name: orientation
children.definition: the particular preferences, tendencies, beliefs or opinions that a person has : khuynh hướng

children.name: political/religious orientation
examples: The meeting is open to everyone, whatever their political or religious orientation.
The party has a broadly socialist orientation.
We employ people without regard to theirpoliticalorsexualorientation.

children.definition: nounJOB
